instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
hi, don't know the history of board as it was bought to use as donor board, but i noticed that <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> switch was missing, so i replaced it and it started working, but now it doesn't detect ssd.
i have checked voltages to j3700 and  <SIGNAL>SMC_OOB1_R2D_CONN_L</SIGNAL> is missing. the problem is it comes from <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>, which is AND gate and signal that should be present on its input comes from smc and its missing.
at this point i am out of ideas, can someone provide any solution?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
That is signal data.
You must check power lines and control first.
SSD should be inserted, of course.
Start posting <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> voltages.

BTW, did you chek a known good SSD?
Start USB OSX and check if Disk Utility sees internal SSD; maybe is not formated...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP> voltages are fine, except <SIGNAL>PP3V3SSD_VMON</SIGNAL>.
as name suggests it should have 3.3 volts but i get around 0.9 volts,(maybe its correct, but i don't have any working board to confirm it)it comes from a voltage divider of <RESISTOR>R3741</RESISTOR>(232k) and <RESISTOR>R3742</RESISTOR>(100k).


edit: did some maths and i think there should be 2 .2 volts drop across 232k resistor l, so i think <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> if working fine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
[QUOTE] btw did you chek a known good SSD?
Start USB OSX and check if Disk Utility sees internal SSD; maybe is not formated...[/QUOTE]
Yeah it came in my mind as well, maybe ssd have high Sierra and board's firmware is not updated to apfs

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
Are you 100% sure all <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> voltages are good???
You already made a bad assumption about pin2.
Why don't you post values?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3SSD_VMON</SIGNAL>: 09V is OK , just calculate the voltage with the resistors values.

Answer to 2Informaticos and post values......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 41376"]Are you 100% sure all <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> voltages are good???
You already made a bad assumption about pin2.
Why don't you post values?[/QUOTE]

Pin 8 of <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> is 3.3v,
pin 3 is 3.3
pin 6 is 3.3
pin 4 is also 3.3.

i have changed <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> yesterday when i thought .9v on pin 2 was wrong, but nothing changed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ssd not detecting
threads.message:
"Pin 8 of <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> is 3.3v,"
Wrong assumption, as imagined...

Pins 7 & 8 should both have 0V.
I hope you checked with SSD inserted.
